items.message:
Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.

Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. However, river levels remain high on the River Thame and Chalgrove Brook, especially in the Dorchester area. Low lying paths, roads and land may remain flooded. River levels are stable and starting to fall in some places. Refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

River levels are falling but are still high at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
Further light rainfall is forecast for the next couple of days. We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the upper river Derwent due to recent heavy rain. Levels have now peaked but will remain high over the coming days. Flooding is expected in this area. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue throughout today, Monday 6 November and into the middle of the week. High water levels may last for a few days. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system and recent rainfall. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue throughout today, Monday 6 November and into the middle of the week. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: The Flood Alert for the New Romney Sewage Arm remains in force due to high water levels in the local drainage system following a week of high rainfall accumulations. The Environment Agency has supplied additional pumping capacity at Greatstone Pumping Station to help draw the water level down. We continue to monitor the level and attend the site on a regular basis.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels remain high on the Horner Water, River Aller, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream and tributaries, which are the areas most at risk. River levels on the Washford River remain high but stable. Further showers are forecast, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days. We have checked weed screens in the area. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely. Please consider local water levels, weather conditions and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 07/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Foulness due to heavy rainfall falling on saturated ground over the last week associated with Storm Ciaran. Flooding remains possible on land around the River Foulness. Levels have now peaked but will remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.38 m and gradually falling. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.

The drain level at Currymoor is 6.59 m and is stable. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m.

Further showers are forecast, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.

We are pumping at Currymoor, Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations with additional temporary pumps installed. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence. Additional pumps at Elson's Clyce are being installed meaning Huntworth Lane will be closed from this evening.

Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated before 03:00 PM on 07/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Ringwood Old Cottage river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch   
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated Wednesday, 08/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We expect river levels to remain high on spring tides until at least 08/11/23.

Flooding is possible for: Rivers Tern, Perry, Roden, Strine and Meese and their tributaries. Be prepared. Flooding is possible in this area. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue throughout today, Monday 6 November and into the middle of the week. High water levels may last for a few days. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system and recent rainfall. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.

Rain over the weekend in the Barlings Eau and Duckpool catchwater area is keeping river levels elevated and will remain high throughout  the next few days. This will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is likely and therefore the Lower Barlings and Short Ferry area flood warning remains in place. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline as the situation changes.

River levels are falling at the Shardlow and Willington river gauge as a result of Storm Ciaran.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Ingleby, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows at Willington,  Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Barlings Eau, Stainfield Beck, Marsh Drain

items.message: We have seen rainfall over the weekend but river levels are continuing to fall and improve, however, we will continue to see flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We urge residents in Short Ferry Caravan Park to remain vigilant and stay up to date with the latest advice. Stay safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water. Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on Floodline as the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Monday 6 November 2023. We are currently seeing higher river levels than normal in the area of Diss. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Diss, Eye, Harleston and Bungay. The forecast is for largely dry conditions with occasional showers today. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation.

Rain over the weekend means that the River Witham remains high, and we will continue to see flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Flood warnings are in effect, and we continue to monitor the bank of the river near Fiskerton village. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages, and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline if the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Monday 6 November 2023. The forecast is for largely dry conditions with occasional showers today. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Monday 6 November 2023. River levels are beginning to drop, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying land and riverside areas around Great Yeldham, Castle Hedingham, Sible Hedingham, Halstead, White Colne, Chappel, Fordstreet, and the Toppesfield Brook, and in Colchester between the A12 and East Street. The forecast is for largely dry conditions with occasional showers today. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation.

River levels are steadily falling. The forecast is largely dry until Wednesday when rainfall could result in the re-issue of this flood alert. items.description: River Witham and associated Fens from Washingborough to Metheringham
items.message: We have seen rainfall over the weekend but river levels are continuing to fall and improve however, we will continue to see flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We are monitoring the bank of the river near Fiskerton village, and have installed cameras to monitor the location continuously. We have agreed an action plan with the Local Resilience Forum should circumstances change. We urge residents in Fiskerton village, Short Ferry Caravan Park and properties along Ferry Road area to remain vigilant, and stay up to date with the latest advice. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring the situation and have staff out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. This message will be updated online and on Floodline as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Waveney from Diss to Bungay
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Monday 6 November 2023. We are currently seeing higher river levels than normal in the area of Diss and Billingford. Areas most at risk are riverside areas in Homersfield, Needham Mill, Brockdish, Scole and Diss, including the A143 at Scole and Homersfield, and the A1066 at Diss. The forecast is for largely dry conditions with occasional showers today. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation.
This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. No further significant rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are high in response to recent rainfall.  Flooding is expected on the Hundred Foot (Ouse) Washes for several days.   This information is correct as of 15:30 on 6/11/23. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 30 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 19 centimetres of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency is liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close Welney causeway. Floodwater is travelling down the River Great Ouse towards the Ouse Washes which will keep levels high for several days. Avoid driving through flood water. We are monitoring the situation.

Flooding is possible in this area.    

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

items.description: Whitwell, Wroxall, Langbridge, Alverstone on the Eastern Yar
River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station (HEPS) is 8.08 m and gradually falling.

The drain level at HEPS is 8.04 m and gradually rising.

Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.

Scattered showers are forecast today, 06/11 therefore flooding remains possible.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely. We are unable to pump at Huish Episcopi and other pumping stations near Langport due to high river levels. However we are utilising the Parrett Relief Channel to evacuate the water (as downstream tidal levels allow).

Please consider local water levels, weather conditions and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 03:00 PM on 07/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message: River levels are falling but remain high, particularly in the levels and moors, after the rain over the weekend. Areas most at risk include the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of the runway, the Mudford to Limington road, the road and properties at the south end of Westover Trading Estate. Further showers are forecast, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely. We will pump when river levels allow us to at Langport later today. Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 07/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Outlying villages on the Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely to continue throughout today, Monday 6 November and into the middle of the week. High water levels may last for a few days. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system and recent rainfall. Areas most at risk are Ridlington, Briggate, Honing, East Rushton, Dilham, Sutton, Catfield Common, Hickling, Potter Heigham, Ludham, Bastwick, Martham, Damgate and Billockby, and the A149 and A1062 roads. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.
This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. No further significant rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. We continue to monitor the situation.

For water levels on the River Tone and Currymoor Drain at Currymoor pumping station please refer to our website: Check For Flooding (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk).
Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst the River Tone level exceeds 7.45 m. 
We are utilising our pumping stations, including additional temporary pumps, as water levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence. 
Further rain including heavy downpours are forecast this week, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to the intense rainfall over the last few weeks, with the borehole at Kingston Russell rising to 115 metres overnight. The more westerly communities on the Chalk in Dorset, including those along the South Winterbourne Valley, Beaminster and Hooke will start to experience issues with septic tanks and roads may become flooded. Levels are expected to continue rising until at least the end of next week. You can monitor groundwater levels at the Kingston Russell borehole on the Check-for-Flooding.gov.uk website. Further heavy rainfall is expected in the middle of next week. Please avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can flood nearby properties and can seriously damage your engine. If there is no alternative please drive very slowly to minimise damage. If you have property flood resilience measures such as pumps, air brick covers or flood barriers, you should consider putting them in place now. This message will be updated on Monday.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
High water levels in the local drainage system are reducing, but still pose a flood risk to low lying land. The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed, properties are no longer at risk. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the area.
We continue to monitor the level and attend the site on a regular basis.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: The Flood Alert for the Lower River Stour remains in force following the day of heavy rainfall on Saturday 4 November. Water levels are now receding slowly around Wye following their peak on Sunday 5 November. River levels remain high between Wye and Fordwich. Drier weather is expected today and Tuesday. This Flood Alert will be updated tomorrow morning, Tuesday 7 November.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole at Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley. Groundwater levels are high and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.

We expect levels to stabilise over the next few days. Low-lying land and roads will therefore also continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message as the situation changes.

Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.   Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen above 99 metres at the Woodyates borehole, Levels are forecast to rise quite steeply for the next 48 hours at least. Flooding of minor roads is possible at this level. Some septic tanks are likely to fail with a continued rise in level. Areas most likely to be affected are the Vale of Allen, including Sixpenny Handley and the Chalke Valley. 
Householders with property level protection measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers should put them in place now.
Motorists should avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage homes and car engines.
This message will be updated tomorrow, Monday

items.description: Pearl Brook at Horwich, area close to the river from Church Street to the M61
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are now falling steadily.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the South Wiltshire Downs - The Dene
items.message:
The level at the nearby Terraces, Fonthill borehole has risen to 116 metres above sea level.  Flooding to properties from groundwater in the Dene Valley is now expected. The stream will remain high for several days. Ensure that pumps are operational and that other precautions such as airbrick covers and flood boards are in place. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave will cause properties to flood. 
Further rainfall is expected on Wednesday and at the beginning of next week which will keep levels high. A high pressure system may bring a brief respite from about the 15th; this may provide an opportunity to replenish any property level resilience measures.
This message will be updated on Tuesday.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
The level at the nearby Kingston Russell borehole has risen to 116 metres above sea level.  Flooding to properties from groundwater in the South Winterbourne Valley is now expected. The Winterbourne will remain high for several days. Ensure that pumps are operational and that other precautions such as airbrick covers and flood boards are in place. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave will cause properties to flood. 
Further rainfall is expected on Wednesday and at the beginning of next week which will keep levels high. A high pressure system may bring a brief respite from about the 15th; this may provide an opportunity to replenish any property level resilience measures.
This message will be updated on Tuesday.
